message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Dynamics on higher-order networks: a review
Paper Abstract: Network science has evolved into an indispensable platform for studying complex systems. But recent research has identified limits of classical networks, where links connect pairs of nodes, to comprehensively describe group interactions. Higher-order networks, where a link can connect more than two nodes, have therefore emerged as a new frontier in network science. Since group interactions are common in social, biological and technological systems, higher-order networks have recently led to important new discoveries across many fields of research. Here, we review these works, focusing in particular on the novel aspects of the dynamics that emerges on higher-order networks. We cover a variety of dynamical processes that have thus far been studied, including different synchronization phenomena, contagion processes, the evolution of cooperation and consensus formation. We also outline open challenges and promising directions for future research.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here are the search results for "Network science":

## Overview

Network science is an academic field which studies complex networks such as telecommunication networks, computer networks, biological networks, cognitive and semantic networks, and social networks, considering distinct elements or actors represented by nodes (or vertices) and the connections between the elements or actors as links (or edges).

## Theoretical Foundations

The field draws on theories and methods including graph theory from mathematics, statistical mechanics from physics, data mining and information visualization from computer science, inferential modeling from statistics, and social structure from sociology.

## History and Development

Interest in networks exploded around 2000, following new discoveries that offered novel mathematical framework to describe different network topologies, leading to the term 'network science'. Albert-László Barabási and Reka Albert discovered the scale-free networks nature of many real networks, from the WWW to the cell.

## Applications

Network science has diverse applications across multiple fields:

- Social network analysis has been used to understand the diffusion of innovation, news and rumors.
- It has been used to examine the spread of both diseases and health-related behaviors.
- It has been used to examine the role of trust in exchange relationships and of social mechanisms in setting prices.
- In criminology, it is being used to identify influential actors in criminal gangs, offender movements, co-offending, predict criminal activities and make policies.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Network science - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_science"},{"title":"The Science Network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Science_Network"},{"title":"Linked: The New Science of Networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linked:_The_New_Science_of_Networks"},{"title":"Energy Sciences Network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Energy_Sciences_Network"},{"title":"Category:Network science - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Network_science"},{"title":"Social Science Research Network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_Science_Research_Network"},{"title":"Fellows of the Network Science Society - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fellows_of_the_Network_Science_Society"},{"title":"Similarity (network science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Similarity_(network_science)"},{"title":"Efficiency (network science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Efficiency_(network_science)"},{"title":"National Science Foundation Network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Science_Foundation_Network"}]

Here are the search results for "Network science":

## Overview

Network science is an academic field which studies complex networks such as telecommunication networks, computer networks, biological networks, cognitive and semantic networks, and social networks, considering distinct elements or actors represented by nodes (or vertices) and the connections between the elements or actors as links (or edges).

## Theoretical Foundations

The field draws on theories and methods including graph theory from mathematics, statistical mechanics from physics, data mining and information visualization from computer science, inferential modeling from statistics, and social structure from sociology.

## History and Development

Interest in networks exploded around 2000, following new discoveries that offered novel mathematical framework to describe different network topologies, leading to the term 'network science'. Albert-László Barabási and Reka Albert discovered the scale-free networks nature of many real networks, from the WWW to the cell.

## Applications

Network science has diverse applications across multiple fields:

- Social network analysis has been used to understand the diffusion of innovation, news and rumors.
- It has been used to examine the spread of both diseases and health-related behaviors.
- It has been used to examine the role of trust in exchange relationships and of social mechanisms in setting prices.
- In criminology, it is being used to identify influential actors in criminal gangs, offender movements, co-offending, predict criminal activities and make policies.

Web search results for query: "Complex systems"

Links: [{"title":"Complex system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_system"},{"title":"Complex adaptive system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_adaptive_system"},{"title":"Category:Complex systems theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Complex_systems_theory"},{"title":"Large-scale Complex IT Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Large-scale_Complex_IT_Systems"},{"title":"Advances in Complex Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Advances_in_Complex_Systems"},{"title":"New England Complex Systems Institute - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_England_Complex_Systems_Institute"},{"title":"Complex and Adaptive Systems Laboratory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_and_Adaptive_Systems_Laboratory"},{"title":"Complex systems biology","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_systems_biology"},{"title":"Complex Systems (journal) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_Systems_(journal)"},{"title":"Complex dynamic systems theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_dynamic_systems_theory"}]

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of complex systems:

## Definition

A complex system is a system composed of many components that interact with one another.(no content)The study of complex systems is an approach to science that investigates how relationships between a system's parts give rise to its collective behaviors and how the system interacts and forms relationships with its environment.

## Key Characteristics

Systems that are "complex" have distinct properties that arise from these relationships, such as nonlinearity, emergence, spontaneous order, adaptation, and feedback loops, among others.(no content)The behavior of a complex system is intrinsically difficult to model due to the dependencies, competitions, relationships, and other types of interactions between their parts or between a given system and its environment.

## Examples

Examples of complex systems are Earth's global climate, organisms, the human brain, infrastructure such as power grid, transportation or communication systems, complex software and electronic systems, social and economic organizations (like cities), an ecosystem, a living cell, and, ultimately, for some authors, the entire universe.

## Interdisciplinary Nature

Complex systems is often used as a broad term encompassing a research approach to problems in many diverse disciplines, including statistical physics, information theory, nonlinear dynamics, anthropology, computer science, meteorology, sociology, economics, psychology, and biology.

## Alternative to Reductionism

Complex systems can be understood as an alternative paradigm to reductionism, which attempts to explain systems in terms of their constituent parts and the individual interactions between them.

Web search results for query: "Synchronization"

Links: [{"title":"Synchronization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synchronization"},{"title":"Clock synchronization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clock_synchronization"},{"title":"Comparison of file synchronization software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_file_synchronization_software"},{"title":"TCP global synchronization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TCP_global_synchronization"},{"title":"Improvisational Team Synchronization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Improvisational_Team_Synchronization"},{"title":"Frame synchronization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frame_synchronization"},{"title":"Talk:Baltic states synchronization with CESA - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Baltic_states_synchronization_with_CESA"},{"title":"Monitor (synchronization) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monitor_(synchronization)"},{"title":"Synchronization (computer science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synchronization_(computer_science)"},{"title":"Synchronization (alternating current) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synchronization_(alternating_current)"}]

I've performed a web search for "Synchronization" and found comprehensive information on this topic. Here are the key findings:

## General Definition

Synchronization is the coordination of events to operate a system in unison.(no content)Systems that operate with all parts in synchrony are said to be synchronous or in sync—and those that are not are asynchronous.

## Major Applications

**Clock Synchronization**: Clock synchronization is a topic in computer science and engineering that aims to coordinate otherwise independent clocks, though real clocks will differ after some amount of time due to clock drift, caused by clocks counting time at slightly different rates.

**Computer Science**: In computer science, synchronization is the task of coordinating multiple processes to join up or handshake at a certain point, in order to reach an agreement or commit to a certain sequence of action.

**Electrical Systems**: In an alternating current (AC) electric power system, synchronization is the process of matching the frequency, phase and voltage of a generator or other source to an electrical grid in order to transfer power.

**Telecommunications**: In telecommunications, frame synchronization or framing is the process by which, while receiving a stream of fixed-length frames, the receiver identifies the frame boundaries, permitting the data bits within the frame to be extracted for decoding or retransmission.

## Biological and Natural Systems

Synchronization is an emergent property that occurs in a broad range of dynamical systems, including neural signaling, the beating of the heart and the synchronization of fire-fly light waves.

Web search results for query: "Contagion processes networks"

Links: [{"title":"Complex contagion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_contagion"},{"title":"Social contagion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_contagion"},{"title":"Behavioral contagion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_contagion"},{"title":"Network Contagion Research Institute - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_Contagion_Research_Institute"},{"title":"Cascades in financial networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cascades_in_financial_networks"},{"title":"Financial contagion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Financial_contagion"},{"title":"Emotional contagion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_epidemic"},{"title":"Sociality and disease transmission - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sociality_and_disease_transmission"},{"title":"Dynamic contagion process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_contagion_process"},{"title":"Contagion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contagion"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of contagion processes in networks:

## Overview

Social contagion involves behavior, emotions, or conditions spreading spontaneously through a group or network.(no content)Recent work involves academics from social psychology, sociology, and network science investigating online social networks.

## Types of Contagion

Contagion processes can be classified into two main types based on threshold requirements:

**Simple Contagion**: In simple contagion, an individual only needs a single exposure to the new behavior.

**Complex Contagion**: Complex contagion is the phenomenon in social networks in which multiple sources of exposure to an innovation are required before an individual adopt the change of behavior.(no content)Information and disease spread as "simple contagions", requiring only one contact for transmission, while behaviors typically spread as "complex contagions", requiring multiples sources of reinforcement to induce adoption.

## Network Structure Effects

Weak ties and small worlds networks are both very good for spreading simple contagions. However, for complex contagions, weak ties and small worlds can slow diffusion.

## Applications

Contagion processes occur across various domains, including financial contagion, which refers to "the spread of market disturbances—mostly on the downside—from one country to the other", and emotional contagion is a form of social contagion that involves the spontaneous spread of emotions and related behaviors.

Contagion processes occur across various domains, including financial contagion, which refers to "the spread of market disturbances—mostly on the downside—from one country to the other", and emotional contagion is a form of social contagion that involves the spontaneous spread of emotions and related behaviors.

Web search results for query: "Evolution of cooperation"

Links: [{"title":"The Evolution of Cooperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Evolution_of_Cooperation"},{"title":"Cooperation (evolution) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Co-operation_(evolution)"},{"title":"Reciprocal altruism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reciprocal_altruism"},{"title":"Mutual Aid: A Factor of Evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutual_Aid:_A_Factor_of_Evolution"},{"title":"Reciprocity (evolution) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reciprocity_(evolution)"},{"title":"Hermann Reinheimer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hermann_Reinheimer"},{"title":"European Union Military Operation in the Republic of Macedonia - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Union_Military_Operation_in_the_Republic_of_Macedonia"},{"title":"The Complexity of Cooperation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Complexity_of_Cooperation"},{"title":"Cooperative coevolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperative_coevolution"},{"title":"The Origins of Virtue - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Origins_of_Virtue"}]

I found comprehensive information about the evolution of cooperation. Here's an overview of the key topics:

## Definition and Core Concept

In evolution, cooperation is the process where groups of organisms work or act together for common or mutual benefits. However, prominent biologists have found the evolution of cooperation fascinating because natural selection favors those who achieve the greatest reproductive success while cooperative behavior often decreases the reproductive success of the actor, which seemed to pose a challenging problem to the theory of natural selection.

## Theoretical Frameworks

**Reciprocal Altruism:** The concept was initially developed by Robert Trivers to explain the evolution of cooperation as instances of mutually altruistic acts.(no content)Reciprocity in evolutionary biology refers to mechanisms whereby the evolution of cooperative or altruistic behaviour may be favoured by the probability of future mutual interactions.

**Game Theory Approach:** The book "The Evolution of Cooperation" details a theory on the emergence of cooperation between individuals, drawing from game theory and evolutionary biology, providing an investigation into how cooperation can emerge and persist as explained by the application of game theory.

## Key Mechanisms

There have been multiple hypotheses for the evolution of cooperation, all of which are rooted in Hamilton's models based on inclusive fitness, hypothesizing that cooperation is favored by natural selection due to either direct fitness benefits (mutually beneficial cooperation) or indirect fitness benefits (altruistic cooperation).

## Historical Perspectives

Mutual Aid: A Factor of Evolution is a 1902 collection of anthropological essays by Russian naturalist Peter Kropotkin exploring the role of mutually beneficial cooperation and reciprocity in the animal kingdom and human societies.

Web search results for query: "Consensus formation"

Links: [{"title":"Consensus decision-making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_decision-making"},{"title":"Consensus dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_dynamics"},{"title":"Consensus (computer science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_(computer_science)"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Reducing consensus to an algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Reducing_consensus_to_an_algorithm"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Consensus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Consensus"},{"title":"Scientific consensus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scientific_consensus"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Method for consensus building - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Method_for_consensus_building"},{"title":"Consensus theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_theory"},{"title":"Consensus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus"},{"title":"Consensus theory of truth - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_theory_of_truth"}]

I've found comprehensive information about consensus formation. Here's what the search results show:

## Overview

Consensus usually refers to general agreement among a group of people or community.

## Consensus Decision-Making

Consensus decision-making is a group decision-making process in which participants work together to develop proposals for actions that achieve a broad acceptance.(no content)Consensus is reached when everyone in the group assents to a decision (or almost everyone; see stand aside) even if some do not fully agree to or support all aspects of it.

## Consensus Dynamics

From a systems perspective, consensus dynamics, also known as agreement dynamics, is an area of research at the intersection of systems theory and graph theory that studies how a group of agents—such as robots, sensors, or decision-makers—interacting over a network can reach a common decision or estimate through local rules and information exchange.

## Scientific Consensus

Scientific consensus is the majority judgment and position by active, qualified experts in a specific scientific discipline to establish a conclusion or fact.(no content)Scientific consensus results from the self-correcting scientific process of peer review, replication of the event through the scientific method, scholarly debate, meta-analysis, and publication of high-quality review articles, monographs, or guidelines in reputable books and journals to establish facts and durable knowledge about the topic.

## Computer Science Applications

A fundamental problem in distributed computing and multi-agent systems is to achieve overall system reliability in the presence of a number of faulty processes, which often requires coordinating processes to reach consensus, or agree on some data value that is needed during computation.

Based on the search results, I found relevant information about higher-order networks. Here's what I found:

## Higher-Order Networks

Higher-order networks are structures designed to process data with higher-order relationships, such as interactions among multiple entities and complex hierarchies, using structures like simplicial complexes and hypergraphs to capture global dependencies and qualitative spatial properties.

### Key Characteristics

While edges in traditional graphs are limited in their modeling capacity as they can only model binary relations among entities, in higher-order networks, it is desirable to permit relations that incorporate more than two entities, which is central to topological domains.

### Types of Higher-Order Domains

Common topological domains used in higher-order networks include abstract simplicial complexes (the simplest form of higher-order domains), extensions of graph-based models that admit hierarchical structures suitable for various applications, and hypergraphs that generalize simplicial complexes and provide more flexibility in defining higher-order relations.

### Properties of Relations

Higher-order domains feature two main types of relations: hierarchies of relations, such as those found in cell and simplicial complexes equipped with rank functions that preserve set inclusion, and set-type relations.

Higher-order networks are increasingly used in applications including topological deep learning, network science, and data analysis where modeling relationships beyond pairwise interactions is important.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title, relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
